presentation.title: What WoT means for the Web

slide.title: Abstract
slide.p: Looking back at the Internet, arguably the biggest impact on how the Internet evolved and developed was the invention of the Web. It can be argued that the nascent Internet of Things (IoT) might take the same trajectory, with first seeing limited and isolated success in specific domains, and then taking off exponentially once those limitations are removed by making the step from IoT to the Web of Things (WoT). This talk is exploring the ways in which IoT and the Web may change once WoT becomes a reality.

ul.li: IoT makes very many things accessible and possibly actionable

li.q: Gartner, Inc. forecasts that 4.9 billion connected things will be in use in 2015, up 30 percent from 2014, and will reach 25 billion by 2020.

ul.li: WoT promises to be the connective layer for IoT things
The Internet's success was greatly accelerated by the Web
The Web's main promise is to avoid verticals and provide an integration layer
Web architecture's model of resources is flexible enough to accommodate IoT
Innovative/useful applications will increasingly include IoT things
Building across verticals can be done most easily with WoT
Creating and using patterns for WoT resources will become essential
No Web-level identification of resources/services
URIs often are resolvable HTTP URIs but don't have to be
Identification (even without interaction) creates a lot of value
Identity and identification are hard problems for real-world resources
Data Fusion works best with known and managed identifiers
Robust naming schemes are needed for all WoT scenarios
The network effect needs relatable identifiers
Actionable identifiers are a (big) plus but not strictly required
No easy way to find existing (i.e., identified) resources
Will there be a Google for the IoT? How would it work in today's/tomorrow's WoT?
Something similar to schema.org may be necessary/helpful
Discovery in IoT probably also needs a robust update channel
The set of discovered resources can change a lot over time
Subscribing to change messages allows clients to stay updated
Many IoT scenarios are tightly controlled verticals
Easier to design and implement for vendors (engineering legacy)
Easier to control and monetize (walled gardens are profitable)
A lot of value can be created by working across silo boundaries
Avoid warehouse approaches selling centralized integration
Prefer ecosystem approaches that with a decentralized architecture
Starting from scratch often is easier than reuse
Many existing designs are not well-documented and extensible
In many cases there is no incentive to reuse
Defining domain models can be hard work

Domain models should be left to domain experts and their organizations
Domain models should be built on their preferred metamodels
Loose Coupling allows clean separation of concerns
Ability to use services without the need for full integration
Domain Driven Design (DDD) tells us to cleanly and clearly separate domains
APIs are contracts and they should be as simple as possible

Media types (or vocabularies) are similarly important for productive interactions
Agreement on generic interactions is a very good foundation
Hypertext Markup Language (HTML) for human-facing form-based interactions
Atom failed (mostly) because of XML but lives on in pockets such as podcasts
Activity Streams may become the "JSON-based Atom" of the future
Linked Data Platform (LDP) is a starting point for exposing RDF-centric collections
The Web is a Service/Interaction Platform
The primary concern is the interaction model (how to navigate a service's resources)
The domain model of the is service secondary (what the resources represent and how they do it)
Hydra is an RDF-centric approach for representing hypermedia
It is an RDF model for many existing and tested interaction patterns for Web services
It includes paging, templated queries, error responses, documentation links, and more
